message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Vertebrates on the brink as indicators of biological annihilation and the sixth mass extinction
Paper Abstract: Significance The ongoing sixth mass extinction may be the most serious environmental threat to the persistence of civilization, because it is irreversible. Thousands of populations of critically endangered vertebrate animal species have been lost in a century, indicating that the sixth mass extinction is human caused and accelerating. The acceleration of the extinction crisis is certain because of the still fast growth in human numbers and consumption rates. In addition, species are links in ecosystems, and, as they fall out, the species they interact with are likely to go also. In the regions where disappearing species are concentrated, regional biodiversity collapses are likely occurring. Our results reemphasize the extreme urgency of taking massive global actions to save humanity’s crucial life-support systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Timeline of extinctions in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_extinctions_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"Holocene extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene_extinction"},{"title":"List of Asian animals extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Asian_animals_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"List of South American animals extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_South_American_animals_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"List of North American animals extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_American_animals_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"List of African species extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_African_animals_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"Category:Holocene extinctions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Holocene_extinctions"},{"title":"List of North American species extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_American_species_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"List of Antillian and Bermudan animals extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Antillian_and_Bermudan_animals_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Holocene extinction:

## Overview

The Holocene or Anthropocene extinction is an ongoing extinction event caused by human activity during the current geological epoch, impacting diverse families of plants and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and invertebrates, as well as both terrestrial and marine species.(no content)It is sometimes also called the sixth extinction.

## Current Extinction Rates

Current extinction rates are estimated at 100 to 1,000 times higher than natural background extinction rates. Some estimates are even higher, with one estimation suggesting the rate could be as high as 10,000 times the background extinction rate, though this figure remains controversial.

## Driving Factors

The Holocene extinction continues into the 21st century, driven by anthropogenic climate change, destruction of wetlands, deforestation, overfishing, ocean acidification, human population growth, economic growth, and increasing consumption, particularly among affluent societies.

## Timeline

The precise timing of the Holocene extinction event remains debated, with no clear consensus on when it began or whether it should be considered distinct from the Quaternary extinction event. However, most scientists agree that human activities are the primary driver of the Holocene extinction.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Holocene extinction:

## Overview

The Holocene or Anthropocene extinction is an ongoing extinction event caused by human activity during the current geological epoch, impacting diverse families of plants and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and invertebrates, as well as both terrestrial and marine species.(no content)It is sometimes also called the sixth extinction.

## Current Extinction Rates

Current extinction rates are estimated at 100 to 1,000 times higher than natural background extinction rates. Some estimates are even higher, with one estimation suggesting the rate could be as high as 10,000 times the background extinction rate, though this figure remains controversial.

## Driving Factors

The Holocene extinction continues into the 21st century, driven by anthropogenic climate change, destruction of wetlands, deforestation, overfishing, ocean acidification, human population growth, economic growth, and increasing consumption, particularly among affluent societies.

## Timeline

The precise timing of the Holocene extinction event remains debated, with no clear consensus on when it began or whether it should be considered distinct from the Quaternary extinction event. However, most scientists agree that human activities are the primary driver of the Holocene extinction.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Biodiversity"

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Global biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_biodiversity"},{"title":"Biodiversity offsetting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_offsetting"},{"title":"Biodiversity hotspot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot"},{"title":"National Biodiversity Centre (Singapore) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Biodiversity_Centre_(Singapore)"},{"title":"List of biodiversity databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_biodiversity_databases"},{"title":"Global Biodiversity Information Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Biodiversity_Information_Facility"},{"title":"Human Biodiversity Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Biodiversity_Institute"},{"title":"Food biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_biodiversity"},{"title":"Yamuna biodiversity park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna_biodiversity_park"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of biodiversity:

## Definition and Measurement

Biodiversity is the variability of life on Earth.(no content)It can be measured on various levels, for example, genetic variability, species diversity, ecosystem diversity and phylogenetic diversity.(no content)Diversity is not distributed evenly on Earth—it is greater in the tropics as a result of the warm climate.

## Global Scale of Life

According to estimates by Mora et al. (2011), there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species. However, about 1.74 million species were databased as of 2018, and over 80 percent have not yet been described.

## Current Biodiversity Crisis

The world is currently experiencing significant biodiversity loss. The planet has lost 58% of its biodiversity since 1970 according to a 2016 study by the World Wildlife Fund.(no content)The rate of species loss is greater now than at any time in human history, with extinctions occurring at rates hundreds of times higher than background extinction rates.

## Main Causes

Destroying habitats for farming is a key reason why biodiversity is decreasing today. Climate change also plays a role.(no content)The cause of most of the biodiversity loss is, generally speaking, human activities that push the planetary boundaries too far. These activities include habitat destruction (for example deforestation) and land use intensification (for example monoculture farming).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Mass extinction"

Links: [{"title":"Late Ordovician mass extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Ordovician_mass_extinction"},{"title":"Extinction event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction_event"},{"title":"Late Devonian mass extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Devonian_mass_extinction"},{"title":"Capitanian mass extinction event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitanian_mass_extinction_event"},{"title":"List of extinction events - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_extinction_events"},{"title":"Permian–Triassic extinction event","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permian–Triassic_extinction_event"},{"title":"Holocene extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene_extinction"},{"title":"End-Botomian mass extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-Botomian_mass_extinction"},{"title":"Triassic–Jurassic extinction event","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triassic–Jurassic_extinction_event/"},{"title":"Category:Extinction events - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Extinction_events"}]

Here's what I found about mass extinctions:

## Definition and Characteristics

A mass extinction (also known as an extinction event or biotic crisis) is a widespread and rapid decrease in the biodiversity on Earth, identified by a sharp fall in the diversity and abundance of multicellular organisms.(no content)Mass extinctions are characterized by the loss of at least 75% of species within a geologically short period of time (less than 2 million years).

## The "Big Five" Major Extinctions

Estimates of the number of major mass extinctions in the last 540 million years range from as few as five to more than twenty. The most significant are:

1. **Permian-Triassic Extinction (The Great Dying)**: This extinction event occurred approximately 251.9 million years ago at the boundary between the Permian and Triassic geologic periods, and is Earth's most severe known extinction event, with the extinction of 57% of biological families, 62% of genera, 81% of marine species, and 70% of terrestrial vertebrate species.

2. **Late Ordovician Extinction**: The Late Ordovician mass extinction is the first of the "big five" major mass extinction events in Earth's history, occurring roughly 445 million years ago.

3. **Late Devonian Extinctions**: These extinction events are one of the "Big Five" most severe mass extinction events in Earth's history, with likely around 40% of marine species going extinct.

## Current Extinction Crisis

Numerous experts believe we are living through, or on the cusp of, a mass species extinction event, the sixth in the history of the planet and the first to be caused by a single organism—us.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Endangered species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_species"},{"title":"Category:IUCN Red List extinct species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:IUCN_Red_List_extinct_species"},{"title":"Lists of extinct species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lists_of_extinct_species"},{"title":"List of North American species extinct in the Holocene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_American_species_extinct_in_the_Holocene"},{"title":"Endangered species (IUCN status) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_species_(IUCN_status)"},{"title":"Category:Extinct species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Extinct_species"},{"title":"Endangered Species Act of 1973 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_Species_Act_of_1973"},{"title":"Critically endangered - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critically_endangered"},{"title":"IUCN Red List endangered species (Animalia) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IUCN_Red_List_endangered_species_(Animalia)"},{"title":"Endangered species recovery plan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_species_recovery_plan"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about endangered species:

## Definition and Overview

An endangered species is a species that is very likely to become extinct in the near future, either worldwide or in a particular region.(no content)Endangered species may be at risk due to factors such as habitat loss, poaching, invasive species, and climate change.

## Conservation Status Categories

The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List lists the global conservation status of many species, and various other agencies assess the status of species within particular areas.(no content)When discussing the IUCN Red List, the official term "threatened" is a grouping of three categories: critically endangered, endangered, and vulnerable.

## Scale of the Problem

Over 50% of the world's species are estimated to be at risk of extinction, but the frontiers between categories such as "endangered", "rare", or "locally extinct" species are often difficult to draw given the general paucity of data on most of these species.

## Conservation Efforts

Many nations have laws that protect conservation-reliant species which, for example, forbid hunting or harvesting, restrict land development, or create protected areas.(no content)Some endangered species are the target of extensive conservation efforts such as captive breeding and habitat restoration.

## Primary Threats

Currently, the biggest reason for species extinction is human interaction resulting in habitat loss.

Web search results for query: "Vertebrate"

Links: [{"title":"Vertebrate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertebrate"},{"title":"Vertebrate paleontology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertebrate_paleontology"},{"title":"Marine vertebrate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_vertebrate"},{"title":"Category:Parasitic vertebrates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Parasitic_vertebrates"},{"title":"Museum of Vertebrate Zoology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Vertebrate_Zoology"},{"title":"Category:Enigmatic vertebrate taxa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Enigmatic_vertebrate_taxa"},{"title":"Western Foundation of Vertebrate Zoology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Foundation_of_Vertebrate_Zoology"},{"title":"List of vertebrate fauna of the Campanian stage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vertebrate_fauna_of_the_Campanian_stage"},{"title":"Domestication of vertebrates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication_of_vertebrates"},{"title":"Category:Vertebrates of Antarctica - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Vertebrates_of_Antarctica"}]

Here are the search results for "Vertebrate":

## Overview

Vertebrates, also called craniates, are animals with a vertebral column and a cranium.(no content)The vertebral column surrounds and protects the spinal cord, while the cranium protects the brain.

## Classification and Diversity

The vertebrates make up the subphylum Vertebrata with some 65,000 species, by far the largest ranked grouping in the phylum Chordata.(no content)The vertebrates include mammals, birds, amphibians, and various classes of fish and reptiles.

## Key Characteristics

Vertebrates are distinguished from all other animals, including other chordates, by multiple characteristics: a vertebral column; a skull of bone or cartilage; a large brain divided into 3 or more sections, a muscular heart with multiple chambers; an inner ear with semicircular canals; sense organs including the eyes, ears, and nose; and digestive organs including the intestines, liver, pancreas, and stomach.

## Evolutionary History

The first vertebrates appeared in the Cambrian explosion some 518 million years ago.(no content)Jawed vertebrates evolved in the Ordovician or Silurian; bony fishes appeared in the Silurian and diversified widely in the Devonian.

## Significance

Despite their prominence, vertebrates still only make up less than five percent of all described animal species.

Web search results for query: "Ecosystem"

Links: [{"title":"Ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem"},{"title":"Ecosystem service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_service"},{"title":"Category:Ecosystems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ecosystems"},{"title":"Payment for ecosystem services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_for_ecosystem_services"},{"title":"Effects of climate change on biomes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_and_ecosystems"},{"title":"Marine ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_ecosystem"},{"title":"Freshwater ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freshwater_ecosystem"},{"title":"Ecosystem diversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_diversity"},{"title":"Forest Ecosystems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forest_Ecosystems"},{"title":"River ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/River_ecosystem"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecosystems:

## Definition and Basic Concepts

An ecosystem is a system formed by organisms in interaction with their environment.(no content)The biotic and abiotic components are linked together through nutrient cycles and energy flows.(no content)Biotic factors are living things such as plants, while abiotic are non-living components such as soil.

## Components and Functions

Plants allow energy to enter the system through photosynthesis, building up plant tissue, while animals play an important role in the movement of matter and energy through the system by feeding on plants and one another.

## Ecosystem Services

Ecosystems provide a variety of goods and services upon which people depend, with ecosystem goods including the "tangible, material products" such as water, food, fuel, construction material, and medicinal plants.(no content)Ecosystem services include things like the maintenance of hydrological cycles, cleaning air and water, the maintenance of oxygen in the atmosphere, crop pollination and even things like beauty, inspiration and opportunities for research.

## Types of Ecosystems

The search results highlight several major ecosystem types:

- Marine ecosystems are the largest of Earth's aquatic ecosystems and exist in waters that have a high salt content, with marine waters covering more than 70% of the surface of the Earth.

- Freshwater ecosystems include the biological communities inhabiting freshwater waterbodies such as lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, springs, bogs, and wetlands.

## Environmental Threats

Many ecosystems become degraded through human impacts, such as soil loss, air and water pollution, habitat fragmentation, water diversion, fire suppression, and introduced species and invasive species.

An ecosystem is a system formed by organisms in interaction with their environment.(no content)The biotic and abiotic components are linked together through nutrient cycles and energy flows.(no content)Biotic factors are living things such as plants, while abiotic are non-living components such as soil.

## Components and Functions

Plants allow energy to enter the system through photosynthesis, building up plant tissue, while animals play an important role in the movement of matter and energy through the system by feeding on plants and one another.

## Ecosystem Services

Ecosystems provide a variety of goods and services upon which people depend, with ecosystem goods including the "tangible, material products" such as water, food, fuel, construction material, and medicinal plants.(no content)Ecosystem services include things like the maintenance of hydrological cycles, cleaning air and water, the maintenance of oxygen in the atmosphere, crop pollination and even things like beauty, inspiration and opportunities for research.

## Types of Ecosystems

The search results highlight several major ecosystem types:

- Marine ecosystems are the largest of Earth's aquatic ecosystems and exist in waters that have a high salt content, with marine waters covering more than 70% of the surface of the Earth.

- Freshwater ecosystems include the biological communities inhabiting freshwater waterbodies such as lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, springs, bogs, and wetlands.

## Environmental Threats

Many ecosystems become degraded through human impacts, such as soil loss, air and water pollution, habitat fragmentation, water diversion, fire suppression, and introduced species and invasive species.

"Biological annihilation" refers to a phenomenon akin to a sixth mass extinction event that is underway as a result of anthropogenic causes, such as over-population and over-consumption, according to a study published in May 2017 in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

The term describes the severe and rapid loss of species populations and biodiversity occurring in modern times due to human activities. This is part of what many scientists call the Holocene extinction or sixth mass extinction—the first mass extinction event in Earth's history to be caused by a single species, humans.

Human-driven factors contributing to biological annihilation include habitat destruction, climate change, overhunting, pollution, invasive species, and agricultural expansion. Humans have driven the rate of biological extinction, the permanent loss of species, up several hundred times beyond its historical levels.
